content: Chapter 5: Principles of Inheritance and Variation

This chapter deals with how traits and characteristics are passed from one generation to the next. It explains the concepts of heredity, genetic principles, Mendel's experiments, and variations observed in living organisms.
1. Introduction

meaning: The branch of biology that deals with the study of heredity and variation.
The transmission of genetic characters from parents to offspring.
Differences in characteristics among individuals of the same species or between generations.

content: Heredity ensures continuity of traits, while variation ensures individuality among organisms.
2. Mendel’s Experiments
Gregor Johann Mendel, known as the Father of Genetics, performed experiments on pea plants (Pisum sativum) to study inheritance patterns.

title: Reasons for Selecting Pea Plant
items: Pea plants have distinct and contrasting traits.
They are easy to cultivate and have a short life cycle.
They can self-pollinate and cross-pollinate easily.

title: Seven Contrasting Traits Studied by Mendel

content: 3. Mendel’s Laws of Inheritance

title: Mendel proposed three laws of inheritance:
items: Law of Dominance
Law of Segregation
Law of Independent Assortment

meaning: When two alleles are combined, one allele (dominant) expresses itself while the other (recessive) remains hidden.
Allele pairs separate during gamete formation, and each gamete carries only one allele for each gene.
Genes for different traits assort independently during gamete formation.

content: Mendel used dihybrid crosses to prove the law of independent assortment.
4. Important Genetic Terms

title: Key Terms and Meanings
rows: A unit of inheritance controlling a specific character.
Different forms of the same gene.
Having two identical alleles for a trait (e.g., TT, tt).
Having two different alleles for a trait (e.g., Tt).
The genetic constitution of an organism.
The observable physical expression of a trait.

content: Punnett Square is used to predict genotype and phenotype ratios in crosses.
5. Monohybrid Cross
A cross involving the inheritance of a single pair of contrasting traits. Example: Tall (TT) × Dwarf (tt).

title: Result of Monohybrid Cross
items: F1 Generation – All tall (Tt)
F2 Generation – 3 Tall : 1 Dwarf (Phenotypic ratio)
Genotypic ratio – 1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt

content: 6. Dihybrid Cross
A cross involving two pairs of contrasting traits. Example: Round Yellow (RRYY) × Wrinkled Green (rryy).

title: Result of Dihybrid Cross
items: F1 Generation – All Round Yellow (RrYy)
F2 Generation – 9 Round Yellow : 3 Round Green : 3 Wrinkled Yellow : 1 Wrinkled Green

content: The phenotypic ratio of a dihybrid cross is 9:3:3:1.
7. Deviations from Mendelian Inheritance

items: Incomplete Dominance – Neither allele is completely dominant (e.g., Snapdragon flower colour).
Codominance – Both alleles express equally (e.g., ABO blood groups).
Multiple Alleles – More than two alleles for a gene (e.g., Blood group gene I).
Polygenic Inheritance – Multiple genes influence a single trait (e.g., skin colour).

content: 8. Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance

meaning: Proposed by Sutton and Boveri, it states that genes are present on chromosomes and their behaviour during meiosis explains inheritance patterns.

content: Mendel’s factors (genes) are located on chromosomes; hence inheritance and chromosomal behaviour are linked.
9. Linkage and Recombination

meaning: The tendency of genes located close together on a chromosome to be inherited together.
The formation of new combinations of genes due to crossing over during meiosis.

content: 10. Sex Determination
Sex determination is the process by which the sex of an individual is established. It depends on specific sex chromosomes.

title: Sex Determination Mechanisms
rows: Male has only one X chromosome

content: 11. Mutation and Genetic Disorders

meaning: Sudden heritable change in DNA sequence leading to alteration in phenotype or genotype.

title: Types of Genetic Disorders
items: Chromosomal disorders – caused by abnormal number or structure of chromosomes (e.g., Down’s syndrome).
Mendelian disorders – caused by mutations in single genes (e.g., Haemophilia, Sickle-cell anaemia).

content: Genetic counselling helps detect and manage hereditary disorders early.
12. Summary

items: Mendel discovered basic laws of inheritance using pea plants.
Inheritance follows predictable patterns through alleles and genes.
Chromosomes carry genes responsible for traits.
Deviations like incomplete dominance and codominance exist.
Sex is determined by specific sex chromosomes.
Mutations and genetic disorders lead to variation and disease.
